awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Forest Water Use and the Influence of Acid Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Forest Water Use Efficiency (WUE) is defined as the ratio of carbon uptake per unit water vapor loss via transpiration. Micrometeorological measurements suggest that forest WUE has dramatically increased over the last two decades, in excess of what would be expected from increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations. Coinciding with observed trends in forest WUE have been marked decreases in acid deposition throughout much of North America and Europe. There is evidence that acid deposition may impact forest WUE, either by altering the availability of nutrients in forest soils or by directly affecting foliar physiology.  Changes in WUE could also lead to changes in stream discharge from forested catchments.  The hypothesized response of forests to changing levels of acid deposition is not currently considered in the land surface components of global climate models (GCMs). Since carbon dioxide and water vapor are the two most important greenhouse gases, it is vital to accurately model their land-atmosphere exchange.
 
The proposed research uses a catchment-based approach to investigate the effects of changing acid deposition on forest WUE. Tree ring carbon isotopes will be used to reconstruct historical WUE time series within six catchments that have been differentially impacted by acid deposition due to distinctions between their underlying bedrock mineralogy and geological histories. The research will also capitalize on experimental treatments that have altered soil biogeochemistry in paired catchment designs (Bear Brook, ME; Hubbard Brook, NH; and Fernow Experimental Forest, WV). Stream discharge analysis and model-based approaches will be applied to detect the impact of acid deposition on forest WUE. 

The project will support a Ph.D. student, who will receive training in a wide range of field, laboratory, and modeling techniques, and at least eight undergraduate students. High school students will also be involved through established programs, and will include their participation in both field and lab activities. All senior members of the project team have track records of recruiting students from underrepresented groups. Results will be communicated to the broader scientific community through journal publications and conference presentations, and a special conference session will be organized with an objective of sharing research findings with the modeling community.

por.por_cntn:
This project tested the hypothesis that historical trends in acid rain, through its influence on soil base cation availability, has altered the amount of water used by forests in the eastern United States. This effect had been suggested by plot- and plant-level studies that linked lower base cation availability with reduced water use efficiency (WUE, the amount of carbon gained by plants per unit water lost via transpiration). Analyses of river and streamflow statistics did not detect this effect on a widespread basis, but evidence in support of the hypothesis was documented in a paired watershed experiment in which one watershed was subjected to several decades of enhanced acidic deposition. Analyses of carbon isotopes in tree rings, which record historical variations in tree WUE, shed some light on these mixed findings. Cores were collected from over 500 trees within eastern U.S. watersheds, spanning gradients in both soil base cation availability and degree of sulfate retention. The historical WUE values inferred from these cores were highly species specific, with more variation seen from species to species than within species across soil types or experimental treatments. In general, coniferous species exhibited WUE trends that were more consistent with trends in atmospheric deposition, while broadleaf deciduous species exhibited WUE trends that were more consistent with rising atmospheric carbon dioxide levels. The mixed composition of eastern U.S. forests potentially diminished the effects of changing acidic deposition on forest WUE and streamflow that emerges from the forested watersheds.

At Rider University, this project supported six undergraduate science majors. Three of these students also had the opportunity to participate in field work at Fernow Experimental Forest in West Virginia and Shenandoah National Park in Virginia, spending full days with the project team collecting soil samples and tree cores. Two students completed a departmental senior thesis on research questions related to this project. Three students also participated in a Forest Water Use symposium at the University of Virginia (UVA), which was attended by all the principle investigators from the collaborative research project, graduate and undergraduate students from the participating universities, as well as scientists from the U.S. Forest Service and outside universities. This symposium coincided with a UVA graduate research conference in environmental sciences, providing Rider undergraduates the opportunity to see graduate student research first-hand. Lastly, after graduation from Rider University, three of these six students accepted offers from graduate science programs while the other three accepted full-time offers in entry-level environmental consulting firms. Findings from the research have been disseminated in scientific journal articles and presentations at scientific meetings. This research has introduced the concept that soil base cation status can potentially regulate forest water use and streamflow, which has implications for water resources management and modeling.
